Get Started

A tiny, pink-powered prompt language.

YAPL is a markdown-first, composable templating language for AI agents. Define blocks, reuse with traits, and inject variables.

Install Open Playground VS Code Extension
MIT Licensed • Zero deps runtime • Works anywhere
hello.yapl 

{# AI Code Reviewer Template #}
{% block system %}
You are an expert code reviewer with deep knowledge of {{ language | default("programming") }}.
{% endblock %}

{% block guidance %}
- Focus on code quality, security, and best practices
- Provide specific, actionable feedback
{% if experience_level == "junior" %}
- Explain the reasoning behind your suggestions
{% endif %}
{% endblock %}

{% block prompt %}
Please review the following {{ language }} code:

```{{ language }}
{{ code }}
```

{% if focus_areas is defined %}
Pay special attention to: {{ focus_areas | join(", ") }}
{% endif %}
{% endblock %}

Why YAPL #

Everything you need to write durable, reusable prompts.

🧱

Blocks

Split prompts into logical blocks (system, guidance, output_format...). Compose them like UI.

🧬

Traits

Attach traits like concise or formal to change tone without duplicating text.

🧩

Variables

Interpolate with {{"{{ var }}"}}. Optional defaults, strict mode, and safe rendering.

📝

Markdown-first

Write prompts as readable docs. Keep formatting deterministic.

🧪

Testable

Snapshot prompts, diff traits, and validate variable contracts.

🧰

Tiny runtime

Ship a ~2KB renderer or compile to JSON for any stack.

Install #

Pick your environment. YAPL ships a CLI and a tiny JS runtime. 

npm i -D yapl-cli
npx yapl init
npx yapl render ./prompts/hello.yapl --vars ./vars.json
pnpm add -D yapl-cli
pnpm yapl init
pnpm yapl render ./prompts/hello.yapl --vars ./vars.json
bun add -d yapl-cli
bunx yapl init
bunx yapl render ./prompts/hello.yapl --vars ./vars.json
deno run -A jsr:@yapl/cli init
deno run -A jsr:@yapl/cli render ./prompts/hello.yapl --vars ./vars.json

Examples #

A few core language patterns.

Blocks & Variables


{# translator.md.yapl #}
{% block system %}
You are a professional translator specializing in {{ targetLanguage | default("English") }}.
{% endblock %}

{% block guidance %}
- Maintain the original tone and style
- Keep technical terms and brand names unchanged
- Preserve formatting and code blocks
{% endblock %}

{% block prompt %}
Translate the following {{ sourceLanguage | default("text") }} to {{ targetLanguage }}:

---
{{ text }}
---
{% endblock %}

Conditional Logic


{# conditional-agent.md.yapl #}
{% extends "base/system.md.yapl" %}

{% block persona %}
{{ super() }}
{% if user_type == "expert" %}
You are an advanced AI with deep technical knowledge.
{% else %}
You are a beginner-friendly AI that explains things simply.
{% endif %}

{% if domain is defined %}
You specialize in {{ domain }}.
{% endif %}
{% endblock %}

{% block guidance %}
{{ super() }}
{% if user_type == "expert" %}
Provide detailed technical explanations with code examples.
{% else %}
Use simple language and avoid jargon.
{% endif %}

{% if include_examples is defined and include_examples %}
Always include practical examples in your responses.
{% endif %}
{% endblock %}

Template Inheritance & Mixins


{# advanced-agent.md.yapl #}
{% extends "../base/system.md.yapl" %}
{% mixin "../mixins/safety.md.yapl", "../mixins/tone_friendly.md.yapl" %}

{% block persona %}
{{ super() }}
{% if role == "teacher" %}
You are an educational AI tutor who loves helping students learn.
{% if subject is defined %}
You specialize in teaching {{ subject }}.
{% endif %}
{% else %}
You are a general-purpose AI assistant.
{% endif %}
{% endblock %}

{% block guidance %}
{{ super() }}
{% if role == "teacher" and experience_level == "beginner" %}
Use simple language, provide examples, and check for understanding.
{% else %}
You can use technical terminology and assume familiarity with concepts.
{% endif %}
{% endblock %}

    • FAQ #

    Is YAPL a real language?

    This page shows an ergonomic design. The demo runtime here is minimal and client-side only.

    How are blocks rendered?

    Blocks render in declaration order. Traits can override blocks or append hints.

    How do defaults work?

    Use {{"{{ var | default: value }}"}}. The demo resolves that pattern.

    Editor support?

    Planned: syntax highlighting, snippets, and LSP diagnostics.
